default: (a) two {@item shortsword|phb|shortswords} or (b) two {@filter simple melee weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon;melee weapon=sand}
(a) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|phb} or (b) an {@item explorer's pack|phb}
A {@item longbow|phb} and a {@item quiver|phb} of {@item arrows (20)|phb|20 arrows}

classFeature.name: Deft Explorer
entries: Your experience traveling through varying environments has taught you techniques for surviving through even the harshest conditions.
Choose either the {@skill Nature} or {@skill Survival} skill. You become proficient with the chosen skill, and your proficiency bonus is doubled when you make ability checks using that skill.

For each minute you spend studying a creature's tracks, you can learn one particular statistic of the creature - chosen from its type, size, speeds, or if it is proficient with the {@skill Acrobatics}, {@skill Athletics}, or {@skill Stealth} skills.
Also, you and creatures you travel with gain the following benefits:

items: Difficult terrain doesn't slow your travel.
You don't need to reduce your pace to travel stealthily.
You can reroll any hit dice you roll once if the result of the die is lower than your proficiency bonus,and use the higher result.
When you finish a short rest, you can reduce your exhaustion level by 1. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Mark of the Hunt
entries: You have developed advanced techniques to track and hunt creatures, making you a relentless adversary.

Once on each of your turns, you can mark a creature that you can see within 90 feet of you for hunting (no action required). Your weapon attacks deal an extra {@damage 1d4} damage of the weapon's type to a creature you've marked for hunting. This damage increases to {@damage 1d6} at 5th level,and to {@damage 1d8} at 11th level.

You have advantage on Intelligence and Wisdom checks related to tracking a creature you've marked for hunting, and while you are within 30 feet of it, you know the creature's location as long as the creature isn't hidden from you and you aren't blinded or deafened. You can have only one creature marked at a time; if you mark another creature, your mark is removed from the previously marked target.
You can mark a creature in this way a number of times equal to the Marks column of the ranger table, and you regain expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

classFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: At 2nd level, you adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. You can't take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: At 2nd level, you have learned to draw upon the magic inherent in nature,allowing you to cast spells.

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries: The Adaptive Ranger table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your ranger spells. To cast one of yourranger spells of 1st level or higher, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of ranger spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the ranger spell list. When you do so, choose a number of ranger spells equal to your Wisdom modifier + half your ranger level, rounded down (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

Casting a spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells. You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new ranger spell requires time spent in commune with the land: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell you prepare.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your ranger spells, since your magic draws on your attunement to nature. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a ranger spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast any ranger spell you have prepared as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag.

classFeature.name: Primal Awareness
entries: Your spellcasting threads your senses through the nature around you: you can cast each of the spells shown in the Primal Awareness Spells table once without expending a spell slot when you reach certain levels in this class. Once you've cast one of these spells, you must finish a long rest before you can cast that spell again.

entries.caption: Primal Awareness Spells
rows: {@spell beast sense}. {@spell locate animals or plants}

classFeature.name: Ranger Archetype
entries: At 3rd level, choose an archetype to strive towards. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 7th, 11th, and 15th level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Hide in Plain Sight
entries: Starting at 6th level, you gain a +5 bonus to Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks while you press yourself against a solid surface made of natural materials, such as a tree or stone wall that is large enough to provide you cover, or such as when you are prone against grassy groundcover, as the materials magically rearrange and mold to provide you appropriate camouflage.
You lose this benefit until the start of your next turn if you move more than 5 feet on your turn while you are within 60 feet of a creature that can see you.

classFeature.name: Land's Stride
entries: Also at 6th level, land around you recognizes you as its protector and provides you safe passage. Non-magical difficult terrain costs you no extra movement, and plants can't slow you down and can't damage you via thorns, spines, or other similar hazards that they have.

classFeature.name: Ranger Archetype Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Evasion
entries: Beginning at 10th level, you can nimbly dodge away from certain area effects, such as a red dragon's fiery breath or an {@spell Ice Storm} spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

classFeature.name: Ranger Archetype Feature
entries: At 11th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Vanish
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can take the {@action Hide} action as a bonus action on each of your turns. Whenever you successfully hide, you become {@condition invisible} and leave no tracks or traces of your presence until the start of your next turn, or until you attack or cast a spell.

classFeature.name: Ranger Archetype Feature
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Feral Senses
entries: At 18th level, you never have disadvantage on attack rolls against creatures you've marked for hunting.
You are also aware of the location of each creature within 30 feet of you, provided that the creature isn't hidden from you and you aren't blinded or deafened.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Foe Slayer
entries: At 20th level, once per turn, you can add your Wisdom modifier to the attack and damage rolls of one weapon attack you make. You can do so after the attack roll, but before determining the attack's outcome.

Also, when you hit a creature that you've marked for hunting with an attack, you can choose to score a critical hit and add an extra {@damage 6d6} damage to the critical hit. You can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Beast Master
entries: The Beast Master archetype embodies a friendship between the civilized races and the beasts of the world. United in focus, beast and ranger work as one to fight the monstrous foes that threaten civilization and the wilderness alike. Emulating the Beast Master archetype means committing yourself to this ideal, working in partnership with an animal as its companion and friend.

subclassFeature.name: Beast Master Magic
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you always have additional spells prepared when you reach certain levels in this class, shown in the Beast Master Spells table. These spells counts as ranger spells for you, and they don't count against the ranger spells you can prepare.

subclassFeature.name: Animal Companion
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can call forth an animal from the wild to serve as your faithful companion,bonding its soul with your own.

You can spend 8 hours of uninterrupted concentration while remaining within a natural habitat to find an animal companion, which follows you faithfully thereafter. You find your first animal companion as part of gaining this feature.

Your companion can be chosen from {@filter any Small or larger single beast of challenge rating 1/4 or lower|bestiary|challenge rating=[&0;&1/4]|type=beast|size=s;m;l;h;g|miscellaneous=!swarm}. However, your DM might only allow certain animals, based on the surrounding terrain and on what types of creatures would logically be present in the area. You can have only one animal companion at a time.

Your animal companion obeys your commands as best it can. It moves and acts during your turn, but you determine its actions, decisions, attitudes, and so on. You and your companion can move and act in any order you choose. If you are incapacitated or absent, your companion acts on its own.
Your companion is trained specifically to fight in unison with you. The following rules apply while it is bonded to you by this feature:

items: It can't take the attack actions in its stat block, but it can make unarmed strikes,which use a {@damage d4} for damage.
It is proficient in two saving throws and two skills of your choice, in addition to its normal saving throw and skill proficiencies.
It understands one language of your choice that you speak.
It gains a bonus to its attack rolls, to its armor class, and to saving throws and skills which it is proficient in. This bonus equals your proficiency bonus minus 2 (minimum of +0).

When you gain this feature, and again for each of your ranger levels above 3rd, your companion gains a hit die and its maximum hit points increase by an amount equal to its Constitution modifier (minimum of 1) plus four. Also, whenever you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from this class, your companion can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or it can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1, to a maximum of 20.

If your animal companion is ever slain, the magical bond you share allows you to return it to life when you finish a long rest. You can return an animal companion to life in this manner even if you do not possess any part of its body. If you use this ability to return a former companion to life while you already have a companion, your current companion leaves you and is replaced by the restored companion.

entries.name: On Creature Proficiency
entries: It can be difficult to discern a creature's proper bonuses, so these tips will help you understand how proficiency and ability scores apply to a creature's statistics. A creature's CR number determines its proficiency bonus as if it were the same level in any class, and its proficiency bonus can't be less than +2 regardless of its CR.

This calculation is incorporated into a creature's stat block for you. For example, a {@creature wolf}'s bite has bonus to hit of +4, a result of adding its proficiency bonus of +2 and its Dexterity modifier of +2. The wolf's bite saving throw DC is set to 11 (8 + its proficiency bonus + its Strength modifier). When you reach 5th level, your companion's proficiency bonus will increase to +3. This increases its bonus to hit to +5 and the saving throw DC of its bite to 12.

subclassFeature.name: Master's Command
entries: Also at 3rd level, you train your companion to follow certain commands in unison with you,improving your bond overtime.

You have a pool of Command Dice equal to half your ranger level + your Wisdom modifier. A command die is a d6, and it is used to issue commands to trained beasts, such as your animal companion. You can issue one command at a time to a trained beast within 120 feet of you that can hear you; the beast must be able to hear you to follow the command, and the command is wasted if the beast doesn't fulfill it before the start of your next turn. Your command die increases in size at certain levels in this class: a d8 at 7th level and a d10 at 11th level.

Your animal companion knows two beast commands of your choice, detailed below. It learns another command when you reach 11th level in this class. You can also teach any friendly beast other than your companion one beast command by spending at least 1 hour per day for 7 days training the creature. Only your companion can ever learn more than one beast command using this feature.
You regain expended command dice when you finish a long rest.
{@b —Beast Commands—}

entries.name: Attack
entries: You can use your bonus action and expend a command die to issue this command. Your companion can use its action to take one of its natural attack actions, except for Multiattack. If the attack hits, roll the die and add the result to the damage roll of the attack.

entries.name: Down
entries: You can use your bonus action and expend a command die to issue this command. Your companion uses its reaction to fall prone and attempt to {@action Hide}, rolling the die and adding the result to its Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check. The first attack it makes while hidden in this way also adds the result of the command die to its attack roll.

entries.name: Find
entries: You can use your bonus action and expend a command die to issue this command. Your companion uses its reaction to attempt to {@action Search} for hidden creatures or objects, rolling the die and adding the result to its Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check for the action.

entries.name: Grab
entries: When your companion makes an {@action opportunity attack}, you can use your reaction and expend a command die to issue this command. If the attack hits, your companion can attempt to {@action grapple} the target as part of the attack, rolling the die and adding the result to the skill check it makes for the attempt.

entries.name: Rush
entries: You can use your bonus action and expend a command die to issue this command. Your companion uses its reaction to take the {@action Help} action, aiding the next attack against a creature within its reach that it can see. If this attack hits, roll the command die and add the result as extra damage for the attack.

subclassFeature.name: Nature's Fury
entries: Starting at 7th level, your companion's attacks count as magical for the purposes of overcoming resistance to non-magical damage.

subclassFeature.name: Beast Whisperer
entries: At 11th level, you gain proficiency with the {@skill Animal Handling} skill if you don't already have it,and your proficiency bonus is doubled for ability checks you make using the skill.

subclassFeature.name: Share Spells
entries: Beginning at 15th level,when you cast a spell that includes you as a target, you can also affect your animal companion with the spell if the animal is within 30 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: Dragonguard
entries: Dragonguards are rangers in stalwart service to dragons. They offer servitude to these proud creatures in the form of defending their territory. In exchange, dragons can offer use of their supernatural abilities to a dragonguard. However, these rangers are wise to remember that dragons are far too intelligent and prideful to be tamed, and that the ire of a dragon is long-lasting.

subclassFeature.name: Dragonguard Magic
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you always have additional spells prepared when you reach certain levels in this class, shown in the Dragonguard Spells table. These spells counts as ranger spells for you, and they don't count against the ranger spells you can prepare.

subclassFeature.name: Dragon Servant
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you are bound to serve a dragon and protect its territory. You can speak, read, and write Draconic. Also, choose one dragon color from the list below, which determines the form your dragonguard features will take and grants you resistance to the color's damage type.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of the Dragon
entries: Also at 3rd level, through a combination of dragon and ranger magic, you can draw the aspect of a dragon into yourself, assuming its form.

You can use your bonus action to transform into a {@creature Dragon Aspect|AdaptiveRanger}. You remain in this form for a number of hours equal to your ranger level, or until you use your bonus action to end the transformation early. Your equipment merges with your form while transformed. You can revert to your normal form early as a bonus action. While transformed, the following rules apply:

items: Your game statistics are replaced with the dragon's, but you retain your ranger features, your proficiency bonus, your Intelligence, Wisdom and Charisma scores, your alignment, and any languages you know.

Your Dragon Aspect gains one hit die and its hit points increase by 8 ({@dice 1d8 + 3}) for each of your ranger levels above 3rd. When you revert to your normal form, you return to the number of hit points you had before you transformed. However, if you revert as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, instead of being knocked unconscious immediately, any excess damage carries over to your normal form. For example, if you take 10 damage in dragon form while you have only 1 hit point left, you revert and take 9 damage.
Your dragon form is immune to the damage type associated with the color you chose for your Dragon Servant feature, and its bite attack deals {@damage 1d4} extra damage of the same type.

You can't cast spells other than those you know from your Dragonguard Magic feature, and you don't need to provide material components for spells you cast in this way. Transforming doesn't break your concentration on a spell you've already cast, however, or prevent you from taking actions that are part of a spell such as {@spell moonbeam}.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Spectral Rider
entries: At 7th level, a spectral, flowing visage of your normal form rides your dragon form, synchronizing your abilities with the dragon's.

Your dragon form gains your normal form's senses, and it becomes proficient in any skills that you are proficient with. Additionally, you can add your proficiency bonus to the damage dealt by your {@spell Dragon's Breath|xge} spell in both your normal form and dragon form.

subclassFeature.name: Frightful Aspect
entries: At 11th level, the dragon aspect within you creates a presence that you can invoke to strike fear into your foes.

You can use your action to choose any number of creatures within 60 feet of you. A chosen creature that can see or hear you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
Once you have used this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Freedom's Wing
entries: At 15th level, you can use your dragon aspect to sprout wings, allowing you to escape danger even while you are not transformed.

As a reaction after you are hit with a melee attack, the attacker must succeed on a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC or be knocked {@condition prone}. You can then fly up to 30 feet without provoking opportunity attacks and float there (if you choose) until the end of your next turn, when you float gently to the ground unless something else is keeping you aloft.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter
entries: Emulating the Hunter archetype means accepting your place as a bulwark between civilization and the terrors of The Wilderness. As you walk the Hunter's path, you learn specialized techniques for fighting the threats you face, from rampaging ogres and hordes of orcs to towering Giants and terrifying Dragons.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter Magic
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you always have additional spells prepared when you reach certain levels in this class, shown in the Hunter Spells table. These spells counts as ranger spells for you, and they don't count against the ranger spells you can prepare.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter's Prey
entries: At 3rd level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Colossus Slayer
entries: Your tenacity can wear down the most potent foes. When you hit a creature with a weapon Attack, you can deal an extra {@damage 1d8} damage to the creature if it's below its hit point maximum. You can deal this extra damage only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Predator Crusher
entries: When a creature within 5 feet of you attacks you, you can use your reaction immediately after its attack to attempt to grapple that creature, provided that you can see the creature. If your attempt succeeds, the creature takes {@damage 1d8} bludgeoning damage. Also, once per turn, you can deal an extra {@damage 1d8} bludgeoning damage when you hit a creature with a weapon attack if it's grappled by you.

subclassFeature.name: Horde Breaker
entries: Once on each of your turns, you can maximize the result of one weapon damage die you roll for a weapon attack, as long as another hostile creature is within 5 feet of the target of your attack. You can do so before or after rolling the damage die.

subclassFeature.name: Stalker's Adaptation
entries: Also at 3rd level, whenever you finish a short or long rest, you can replace your chosen {@subclassFeature Hunter's Prey|Adaptive Ranger|AdaptiveRanger|Hunter|AdaptiveRanger|3|AdaptiveRanger} feature with another feature of your choice from the same list. When you later gain a feature from {@subclassFeature Defensive Tactics|Adaptive Ranger|AdaptiveRanger|Hunter|AdaptiveRanger|7|AdaptiveRanger}, {@subclassFeature Multiattack|Adaptive Ranger|AdaptiveRanger|Hunter|AdaptiveRanger|11|AdaptiveRanger}, and {@subclassFeature Superior Hunter's Defense|Adaptive Ranger|AdaptiveRanger|Hunter|AdaptiveRanger|15|AdaptiveRanger}, you can also replace your choice for those features with different choices from the respective features' lists.

subclassFeature.name: Defensive Tactics
entries: At 7th level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Escape the Horde
entries: Opportunity attacks against you are made with disadvantage, and when an opportunity attack misses you, your speed increases by 10 feet until the end of your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Multiattack Defense
entries: When a creature hits you with an attack, you gain a +4 bonus to your AC against all subsequent attacks made by that creature for the rest of the turn.

subclassFeature.name: Steel Will
entries: You have advantage on saving throws you make when you repeat your saving throw against any ongoing effect.

subclassFeature.name: Multiattack
entries: At 11th level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Volley
entries: As an action, you can make a ranged attack against any number of creatures within 10 feet of a point you can see within your weapon's range. You must have ammunition for each target, as normal,and you make a separate attack roll for each target.

subclassFeature.name: Whirlwind Attack
entries: As an action, you can make a melee attack against any number of creatures within reach of a weapon you are holding, with a separate attack roll for each target.

subclassFeature.name: Superior Hunter's Defense
entries: At 15th level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Stand Against the Tide
entries: When a hostile creature misses you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to force that creature to repeat the same attack against another creature (including itself) of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: When an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the attack's damage against you.

subclassFeature.name: Primeval Watch
entries: Rangers of the primeval watch archetype skulk the borders of ancient forests, woodlands and natural preserves, as they consider it their duty to preserve these bastions of primal life. Their creed affords the primeval watch protection in kind, enhancing their bodies with the nature magic they command.

subclassFeature.name: Primeval Watch Magic
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you always have additional spells prepared when you reach certain levels in this class, shown in the Primeval Watch Spells table. These spells counts as ranger spells for you, and they don't count against the ranger spells you can prepare.

subclassFeature.name: Guardian Soul
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you gain the ability to magically don a tree-like shell, covered with leaves and bark.
As a bonus action, you assume this guardian form, which lasts until you end it as a bonus action or you are incapacitated. You undergo the following changes while in this form:

items: You gain temporary hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier when you use this feature, as well as at the start of each of your turns, which last until your guardian form ends.
Your reach increases by 5 feet.
When you cast a ranger spell that deals damage, you can add your Wisdom modifier to each of the spell's damage rolls.

entries.name: Guardian Soul Note
entries: Guardian Soul doesn't apply to the {@classFeature Mark of the Hunt|Adaptive Ranger|AdaptiveRanger|1|AdaptiveRanger} feature, but it does apply to the {@spell hunter's mark} spell. The feature works here due to that change, but to make it work with any other style of ranger, exclude hunter's mark from gaining the benefits of Guardian Soul.

subclassFeature.name: Piercing Thorns
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can briefly sprout sharp defensive thorns.

Whenever you are hit with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to deal {@damage 1d8} piercing damage to your attacker. This damage increases to {@damage 2d8} when you reach 11th level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Ancient Fortitude
entries: At 7th level, you endure like an ancient tree. While in guardian form, your AC increases by 2, and can add your Wisdom modifier to your Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws.

subclassFeature.name: Rooted Defense
entries: At 11th level, you can project vine and bark which layers the ground around you, slowing your foes and protecting your allies.

While you are in your guardian form, the ground within 20 feet of you becomes difficult terrain. You can choose any number of creatures when you activate your guardian form, who ignore this difficult terrain and have half cover within the area instead.

subclassFeature.name: Ironwood Bark
entries: At 15th level, your bark has become exceptionally hardy and resilient. You can add half of your ranger level to the temporary hit points you gain from your guardian form.

spell.name: Conjure Barrage
entries: You throw a piece of ammunition or a weapon you are holding, and a hazardous barrage of identical weapons bursts forth in a cone originating from you. Each creature in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 4d8} damage of the weapon's type on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Until the end of your next turn, the area becomes covered with sharp fragments of the weapon or ammunition; when a creature enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, you can cause one of the fragments to strike at the creature (no action required). Make a melee spell attack against the creature. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 2d8} piercing damage.
When the spell ends,the fragments created by it disappear.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: The initial damage of this spell increases by {@damage 1d8} for each spell slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Cordon of Arrows
entries: You enchant up to four pieces of nonmagical ammunition - arrows or crossbow bolts - which hover near you for the duration. Until the spell ends, whenever a creature other than you comes within 30 feet of the ammunition for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there, you can have one piece of ammunition fly up to strike it. The creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 1d8} piercing damage. The piece of ammunition is then destroyed. The spell ends when no ammunition remains.
When you cast this spell, or as an action, you can plant any number of the pieces in the ground within 5 feet of you and lay magic upon them to protect an area.
When you cast this spell, you can designate any creatures you choose,and the spell ignores them.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the amount of ammunition that can be affected increases by two for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Healing Spirit
entries: You call an intangible spirit to a cubic 5-foot space you can see. When the spirit appears, it restores {@dice 1d6} hit points to up to two creatures of your choice within 5 feet of it. You can use your bonus action to move the spirit up to 30 feet to a space you can see and repeat this healing effect. The spirit can't heal constructs or undead.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: For each slot level above 2nd, the spirit heals {@dice 1d6} additional hit points, and you can target one additional creature that is within 5 feet of the spirit when you use the spell's bonus action.

spell.name: Lightning Arrow
entries: As part of the casting of this spell, you must make a ranged weapon attack against a creature within range, using a ranged or thrown weapon you are holding, or else the spell fails. The weapon (if thrown) or its ammunition transforms into a bolt of lightning which surges to the target, ignoring cover. On a hit, the target suffers the attack's normal effects and takes an additional {@damage 4d10} lightning damage. On a miss, the target takes half as much damage.

Hit or miss, each creature in a 5-foot-wide line between you and the target, as well as each creature within 10 feet of the target, must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 4d8} lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The weapon or ammunition then returns to its normal form.

components.m: a weapon capable of making ranged attacks

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: For each slot level above 3rd, the additional lightning damage dealt on a hit increases by {@damage 1d10}, and the amount of damage a creature takes on a failed saving throw increases by {@damage 1d8}.

spell.name: Zephyr Strike
entries: Winds sweep over you and carry your arms and legs, allowing you to quickly move and strike. Your movement does not provoke attacks of opportunity until the spell ends.

Immediately after you cast the spell, or as a bonus action once before the spell ends, you can move up to 30 feet and make one melee spell attack against a creature within 5 feet of you, dealing force damage equal to {@damage 1d8} plus your spellcasting ability modifier to the target on a hit.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) piercing damage.
Rangers that follow the archetype of the Dragonguard are able to transform themselves into the Dragon Aspect, gaining various benefits.

system.activation.condition: after you are hit with a melee attack
hit a creature with a weapon attack while it's below its hit point maximum
a creature within 5 ft. of you attacks you
another hostile creature is within 5 ft. of the target of your attack
a creature hits you with an attack
a hostile creature misses you with a melee attack
an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack
Whenever you are hit with a melee attack

entries.name: The Adaptive Ranger
entries: Seeing the unique identity that ranger has, many have come up with great ideas that flesh out that identity even further, adding unique new abilities which make the ranger even more fun to play. I love these brews, but I have sought out to create a ranger that envelopes the ideas of the original ranger and simply allows them to be more verstaile. The ranger is cunning, adaptable, and provides useful insight to the rest of the party - and I think these changes go a long way towards allowing you to live that fantasy.

These changes do make this ranger somewhat more powerful  than its base - the PHB ranger. The most impactful and flavor- neutral changes here are the ones to hunter's mark and the ranger  spells. If you find this ranger to be too powerful for your campaign, I would first revert the spell changes before trying anything else.

entries.name: Design Goals
entries: When I look at the ranger, I see a small list of fundamental issues. None of these have to do with the ranger's identity; they are all mechanical stumbling blocks that make the ranger hard to use. The problems I sought to fix when writing this brew are as follows:

items: The ranger should be a skilled tracker and hunter. Their profession, and sometimes passion, lies in keeping the outskirts of civilization safe. It is also mentioned that they can often travel between civilizations, experiencing vastly different enemies and terrains. Why, then, do rangers turn a blind eye to all but one type of enemy and terrain? Shouldn't they adapt to each situation presented faster than anyone else?

Rangers' offense is often relegated to debuff-attack, without much variety. This is because their spellcasting ability and many of their spells are heavily limited, and I believe this is intended to offset their combined ranged and tracking capabilities. However, in play, this leaves them a set of dull options that are almost entirely prevented from interacting with each other. Adding new ways to use their spells, and lifting some of the constraints, helps alleviate the issues.

Their abilities are all passive. This makes them completely forgettable - as such, I've never met a ranger who remembers every passive benefit they get at all times, or a DM who can accurately account for a ranger. It also gives little incentive to role-play your class. Many people can compensate for this with clever character background, but a ranger's class is far less ingrained into the character's persona than, say, a druid or a paladin would be. You should feel like nobody can hide from you because of your skills, not simply be granted said skills without the satisfaction of earning them.

entries.name: Other Changes
entries: A few other changes here can be applied to other classes and were merely a liberty. The spell {@spell healing spirit|AdaptiveRanger} has been nerfed to a level I feel comfortable with. You can also use the changes to Ranger's spells known with many different kinds of homebrew rangers, as well as the PHB and Revised rangers. The overhaul to the Beast Master archetype should work with any version of the Ranger out there. There may be other changes like these in the document, but these are the easiest to adapt to almost any game.

entries.name: Questions? Feedback?
entries: Thank you for taking the time to read, review and enjoy this homebrew. Feel free to contact me on reddit: {@link /u/devikyn|https://www.reddit.com/u/devikyn} with your comments and improvements!
